credentialSubject.title: Poisoned Attestation
credentialSubject.description: This schema extends the generic Attestation Schema to define an attestation that a component is poisoned

component.description: Component reference, including an ID and hash for the VC claim.

id.description: The component ID (unique identifier) of the VC claim.

hash.description: Cryptographic hash (e.g., SHA-256) for verifying the integrity of the VC claim.

type.description: Type of attestation, set to "Poisoned" for this schema.

poisoning.description: poisoning event that applies to the particular component

date.description: The date of the data poisoning event

type.description: The type of data poisoning event (e.g. mislabelling attack, data injection, data manipulation)

credentialSubject.context:
## Introduction

The **Poisoned Attestation Schema** extends the generic Attestation Schema to enable attestations related to data poisoning. By referencing poisoning event details such as the type of poisoning (e.g. mislabelling attack, data injection, data manipulation, etc.), the date and severity, this schema ensures a structured way to document and track reported data poisoning events.

### Description
This schema includes:
- **Type**: The attestation type, set to "Poisoning".
- **Poisoning Details**: Provides details of the data poisoning event, including poisoning type, date, severity & description.

## Use Case

The **Poisoning Attestation Schema** is used to:
1. **Document Poisoning events**: Attach details of poisoning events to attestations for components.
2. **Track Poisoning**: Keep track of components which have been poisoned and trace which other components this affects.
3. **Support Compliance**: Ensure that poisoned components are tracked and managed in line with security standards.

This schema promotes transparency and accountability, ensuring that data poisoning event information is communicated clearly across software supply chains and trace if a data poisoning event compromises any components in that supply chain.
